fast-setup.name: fast-setup
fast-setup.description: Here we will configure a project in Node.Js to use typescript and after run this example with The Way.

fragments.name: tsNode
fragments.description: This section will describe how to setup your application to be ready to use the framework.

guides.description: First of all we need to create a NodeJs project, so let's create a directory
guides.code: mkdir my-the-way-project

guides.description: Now we need to init the project with the command below
guides.code: npm init -y

guides.description:
Let's add the typescript libraries and the nodemon(is way to watch the change files and recompile)
NPM:
guides.code: npm i typescript nodemon ts-node --save-dev

guides.description: or Yarn
guides.code: yarn add typescript nodemon ts-node --dev

guides.description: Initializing your project to use Typescript
guides.code: ./node_modules/.bin/tsc --init

guides.description: Now we need to create a directory structure, we suggest the follow structure:
guides.code:
my-the-way-project ->
   src ->
      main ->
         YOUR-PROJECT-DIRECTORIES-AND-FILES
      test ->
         YOUR-TESTS

guides.description:
We need to update the tsconfig.json with the follow:
Note: The outDir is the directory where the compiler will put the "builded" files. With the builded files we can execute with node.The include object tell do the compiler the files that needs to be compiled.
guides.code:
{
    "compileOnSave": false,
    "compilerOptions": {
        "baseUrl": "./",
        "downlevelIteration": true,
        "outDir": "./dist/out-tsc",
        "sourceMap": true,
        "declaration": false,
        "module": "esnext",
        "moduleResolution": "node",
        "emitDecoratorMetadata": true,
        "experimentalDecorators": true,
        "importHelpers": true,
        "resolveJsonModule": true,
        "target": "es2015",
        "typeRoots": [
            "node_modules/@types"
        ],
        "lib": [
            "es2018",
            "dom"
        ]
    }
}

guides.description: Now we create a main.ts file at src/main/main.ts to test if everything is ok
Let's create a nodemon.json to watch your files
Now in your project lets add some script's in to your package.json

Now we can execute an test if the main.ts are executed, to do that you only need to execute:
NPM:
guides.code: npm run serve

guides.description: Or Yarn:
guides.code: yarn serve

core.name: core
core.description:
The class CORE is the heart and mind of this framework. It's is responsable to build the dependency tree, inject, configure and destroy.
Also, you can watch when everything is ready, when every is destroyed =(, you can get an instance by name, you can get all instances that are injected and you can destroy.

fragments.name: ready
fragments.description:
We provided an observable to tell you when everything is ready(all configurations are done, all injections are done, all overridden are done), to use this you only need to get the core instance and call the method: whenReady.
Note: the initial value of this observable is false.

guides.description: Using the method whenReady

fragments.name: instance-by-name
fragments.description:
When you want to inject a class in another class the default way to do that is using the @Inject decorator. But sometimes we don't want to inject a class but we want to get the instance at runtime and use this. So, we provided a way to get a instance at runtime.
Note: You only can get an instance that is decorated with @Service, @Configuraation or is an injection of another class.

guides.description:
To get an instance you need to use the method getInstanceByName(instanceName: string), where T is the class and instanceName is the name that class you want to get.
Note: The type or class is optional.
See the code below:
guides.code: CORE.getCoreInstance().getInstanceByName<SecurityService>('SecurityService');

fragments.description:
You can destroy everything. With this method's all the configurations done, the http server builded and the injections will be destroyed. The classes that extends AbstractConfiguration or extends the Destroyable class, will be destroyed when the method destroy of the core is called.
Note:yours classes that extends AbstractConfigurration or Destroyable MUST implement correctly the method destroy(): Observable emitting the value true when all the conections or things that must be destroyed are destroyed.

rest.name: rest
rest.description: This framework provide for your application a loot of decorators to user REST concepts more easealy. You can map a path with the decorators like @Post, @Get, @Put, @Delete and others. You can inject into your method parameters from the request or context of the request using the decoratos like: @PathParam, @BodyParam, @QueryParam, @Header, @Claims, @Request and @Response. Also, you can verify if the user has a token and if  has a certain profile inside the token claims of the user, with that you can enable or reject requests with safetily. You can change some behavior like the security service providing your custom security service.

fragments.name: other-decorators
fragments.description:
The sections below will describe all the decorations that can be injected as parameter into your rest methods.
Note: Some scenarios you can put more than one argument rest decorator.

guides.description: @QueryParam is responsible to bring the query parameters passed in the url to an object. To use this decorator you only need to put into your method an argument with @QueryParam.
@BodyParam is responsible to bring the body passed in the request. To use this decorator you only need to put into your method an argument with @BodyParam.

@PathParam is an argument passed in the url where sometimes is used to pass an id or an identifier. To use this decorator you must provide in your method an argument with @PathParam('VARIABLE_NAME') where VARIABLE_NAME is the parameter from url.

@Claims is an argument from the token. When you generate the token you pass some things like user profiles, username and others, with this decorator you can retrieve that informations from the token. To use this it's very simple you only need to put an argument with @Claims
@Request is the current request. To use this you only need to put an argument with @Request.
@Response is the current response. You can send the response with that. To use this you only need to put an argument with @Response.
@Header is the header of the request. To use this you only need to put an argument with @Header.

Not automatic: A class decorated with @Application and with the parameter automatic=false, will not start automatically. To start you must create the instance.
Custom classes part 1: A customized class
Custom classes part 2: A main class with custom class

fragments.name: configure
fragments.description: Is a decorator designed for configurations or things that need to started like database connections, servers and others. When you decorate a class with that you must extends the class AbstractConfiguration and implement the methods: configure(): Observable<boolean> and destroy(): Observable<boolean>, the method configure will be called at the init of the application and must stream true when the configuration/connection are done. The destroy method is called when the core will be destroyed and must stream true when all configurations/connectios are closed or destroyed. Also, when is provided in the decorator a class, this means, that class must be overridden for the current class decorated with @Configuration
